Project Number: 45518  
Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (PATA) 
December 2011 
 
 
 
People’s Republic of China:  
Enhancing the Energy Regulation System for Low-
Carbon Development
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During the 2010 country programming mission, the People’s Republic of China (PRC) 
requested that the Asian Development Bank (ADB) provide technical assistance (TA) to conduct 
a study on enhancing the energy regulation system for low-carbon development in the PRC. 
The TA is included in ADB’s nonlending program for 2011.1 The concept paper was approved 
on 9 November 2011. During the fact-finding mission, understandings were reached with the 
Government  of  the  People's  Republic  of  China  regarding  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs, 
implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and outline terms of reference for 
the TA. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The  primary  energy  consumption  of  the  PRC  increased  rapidly  from  approximately 
1 billion tons of coal equivalent (tce) in 1990, to 2 billion tce in 2004, and 3 billion tce in 2009. 
Soaring energy demand is both a driver and a consequence of the rapid economic growth in the 
PRC. However, the PRC’s per capita energy consumption is still very low, only about one-third 
of the average of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries.2 It is 
expected  that  in  the  foreseeable  future,  the  PRC’s  energy  demand  and  consumption  will 
continue  to  grow.  Some  estimates  show  that  before  2015,  the  PRC’s  primary  energy 
consumption will exceed 4 billion tce.  
 
3.  The PRC has grown from being a minor and largely self-sufficient energy consumer to a 
major importer. In 2010, it was the second-largest oil importer behind the United States. Of its 
approximately 429 million tons of oil consumption in 2010, 226 million (or more than half) was 
imported.3 Apart from oil, natural gas and coal consumption has also increased rapidly. In 2010, 
the PRC imported approximately 12 million tons of natural gas and 160 million tons of coal.4 The 
increasing reliance on the import of fossil fuels is causing concerns for PRC energy security.  
 
4.  Increased fossil-fuel consumption has also worsened environmental pollution, sharply 
increasing greenhouse gas emissions and casting serious doubts on the sustainability of the 
current  energy-intensive  economic  growth  pattern.  The  government  has  recognized  that 
sustaining economic growth will not be possible without efforts to remove constraints on energy 
supply and stop environmental degradation. To promote the development of a modern energy 
industry, the government has been steadily advancing reforms, including promoting the market-
based regulation system and optimizing the low-carbon energy supply mix.  
 
5.  In the PRC, many national and local government agencies share energy policymaking 
and implementing responsibilities. The National Energy Leading Group of the State Council, 
established  in  2005,  is  the  highest  decision-making  body.  The  National  Development  and 
Reform  Commission  (NDRC)  and  the  National  Energy  Administration  (NEA),  a  partially 
independent ministry under the NDRC, are major agencies responsible for formulating energy 
sector development strategies, developing energy policy, and coordinating between ministries. 
In general, the NEA is responsible for energy supply, while the NDRC takes the lead in energy 
efficiency, energy pricing, and industry regulation. Several other ministries also have important

roles in some specific areas. For example, the Ministry of Land and Resources oversees the 
exploitation of fossil-fuel resources and reserves. The Ministry of Water Resources oversees 
hydropower resources. The Ministry of Agriculture is responsible for rural energy development. 
The Ministry of Finance participates in any reforms involving financial incentives, tax reforms, 
and fees. The State Electricity Regulatory Commission plays a key role in power sector reform 
and electricity market regulation. Finally, the provincial and municipal counterparts of these 
agencies must implement energy policies made by the national government agencies.  
 
6.  While the PRC's energy regulation system is robust and has served the sector well 
during its rapid growth, it needs further refinements and harmonization to make the energy 
sector more market-oriented. The energy regulation system has shortcomings that need to be 
rectified. Foremost, it does not involve a comprehensive energy law. It should set out the basic 
principles that subsidiary sector laws should follow. It should also define and reorganize, if 
necessary, the responsibilities of various ministries in relation to energy5 The PRC’s energy 
.
regulation challenges are largely shaped by its national economic policy goals. Paramount 
among them is the need to sustain its strong economic growth, but in a way that is more 
environmentally  sustainable  than  has  so  far  been  the  case.  In  response  to  the  rapid 
development of the domestic energy market and changes in policy priorities in the Twelfth Five-
Year Plan, the new energy law has to reflect latest developments in market-based energy 
regulation abroad and adapting them to the PRC’s context.  
 
7.  Some sector laws and regulations have become outdated and should be revised to 
reflect  the current  market  situation.  For  example,  the  electricity  law  should  be  updated  to 
promote electricity market reform, streamline the investment mechanism, and assist renewable 
energy integration. The separation of generation from transmission and distribution after 2002 
enabled introduction of wholesale and retail competition, but how the grids will be regulated has 
yet to be decided. Also, the government has shown increasing willingness to use economic 
levers to influence energy supply and demand. Decisions about feed-in tariffs for preferred 
technologies, particularly those using renewable sources, will affect investments and energy 
supply mix in the future.  
 
8.  The rapid rise in energy imports increases demand for international cooperation on 
energy, which requires a harmonized relationship between domestic energy regulations and 
international practices. As in many Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development 
countries, an emergency oil stock is needed to withstand any disruption in supply of oil. In this 
regard, it is essential to study international practices and their relevance to the PRC. The 
operational mechanism for this emergency stock should also be developed. Transboundary 
issues like hydropower development on international rivers and ocean energy utilization have to 
be studied. It is critically important that domestic laws and regulations are harmonized with 
international laws.  
 
9.  The existing energy infrastructure in the PRC, along with its regulatory arrangements, 
was developed for the fossil fuel-based economy and inherited from the previous, centrally 
planned system. While the PRC is accelerating its market-oriented reforms, there is an urgent 
need to comprehensively analyze the above-mentioned issues and help the PRC create an 
enabling regulatory environment for energy sector development. The establishment of an open, 
transparent, and orderly energy regulation system will pave the way for future reforms and the 
rapid and smooth development of the energy sector in the PRC. 
 
                                                 
5  IEA. 2007. World Energy Outlook. Paris.

3
10.  The PRC is a middle-income country with a sizable number of poor people. Sustaining 
strong economic growth will be vital for poverty reduction and inclusive development. But it will 
not be possible without ensuring environmental sustainability and security of energy supply. 
Recognizing the close links between economic growth, energy demand, and environmental 
protection, the PRC has already formulated many reforms to correct the current growth pattern.  
 
11.  In Strategy 2020,6 ADB has defined energy as a core operational sector and achieving 
environmental sustainability as a strategic priority in helping its developing member countries 
reduce poverty and improve living conditions. Its country partnership strategy, 2011–2015 for 
PRC,  which  is  being  finalized,  lists  as  priorities  low-carbon  development,  knowledge  and 
financing to catalyze policy, and regulatory reforms to drive innovation. This TA is expected to 
strengthen the legal and regulatory frameworks in the PRC, promote the utilization of renewable 
energy and strengthen the market-based regulation system to improve energy intensity, and 
help reduce greenhouse gas emissions. There is a strong and direct link between this TA and 
ADB’s operational priorities. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
12.  The impact of the TA will be intensified energy sector reforms to promote low-carbon 
development. The target of the TA impact will be improvement by 2015 of energy intensity by 
16%, and of carbon intensity by 17%, compared with 2010. The outcome of the TA will be an 
enhanced energy regulation system and stronger institutional capacity in energy policy research. 
The target of the TA outcome is that the NEA endorses policy recommendations made under 
the TA in 2013. The TA will help the PRC create a more enabling environment for energy 
market mechanisms. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
13.  The TA is expected to deliver the following outputs: 
 
(i)  An integrated study on the PRC’s current energy regulation system and legislation, 
and their adequacy for its future low-carbon transformation.  
(ii)  Policy recommendations in drafting the energy law and amending the electricity law. 
(iii)  Capacity development and information dissemination. A policy note on main TA 
findings will be prepared and shared with government officials, and workshops, 
seminars, and conferences will also be organized.  
 
14.  General consultations have been conducted with the NEA, the Ministry of Finance, and 
other government agencies concerned on the key activities of the TA. During implementation, 
close coordination will be maintained with stakeholders to ensure that the TA takes into account 
existing studies, government priorities, and development plans. Experts from research institutes 
and universities will be consulted so as to increase understanding of current practices and find 
pragmatic methods for enhancing the energy regulation system. Consultants will be required to 
examine international best practices and compare lessons learned with the PRC’s economic 
environment. The consultants will also be required to maintain close working relations with ADB 
                                                 
6  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila.

4  
and the NEA. Tripartite meetings among ADB, the NEA, and the consultants will be held 
periodically to provide guidance to the consultants and to review their reports.  
 
15.  The  TA  includes  innovative  ideas  and  approaches,  but  the  associated  risks  are 
considered  manageable.  The  key  assumption  for  the  TA  is  that  the  government  remains 
committed  to  building  a  market-oriented  energy  sector.  Since  the  TA  is  in  line  with  the 
government’s development plan to maximize environmental sustainability and strengthen its 
market-based regulation system to improve energy efficiency, the NEA has good ownership of 
the  TA.  To  ensure  that  the  designed  outputs  can  be  delivered  on  time,  the  project  team 
extensively discussed the TA outline and key outputs with relevant government officials and 
experts, while support from the management of the NEA was sought on the TA design.    
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $400,000 equivalent.  ADB will provide $400,000 
equivalent  on  a  grant  basis  from  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other 
sources). The government will provide in-kind contributions in the form of office accommodation, 
logistics facilities, and remuneration of counterpart staff. The cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 18 months from February 2012 to August 2013. The 
NEA is the proposed executing and implementing agency. The NEA has nominated senior 
officials  from  its  Department  of  Policies  and  Laws  to  guide  the  TA  formulation  and 
implementation on a daily basis.  
 
18.  The TA will be carried out by a team of consultants with extensive knowledge and 
expertise in (i) energy development strategy, (ii) energy economics, (iii) energy legislation, 
(iv) electricity reform, and (v) energy-related environmental and social safeguards. The outline 
terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. ADB will select and engage consultants 
through a consulting firm in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time) using the quality- (80%) and cost-based (20%) selection method. 
The consulting firm will be required to submit a biodata technical proposal covering team 
composition,  task  assignments,  work  and  personnel  schedules,  and  CVs  of  proposed 
consultants.  All  procurement  will  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). All equipment purchased under the TA will be 
turned over to the executing agency after TA completion. To ease TA implementation, an 
advance payment facility is requested, and TA funds will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
19.  Activities for capacity development and information dissemination, such as seminars, 
workshops,  conferences,  and  study  tours,  will  be  finalized  during  TA  implementation  and 
administered by the executing agency with the support from the consultants. The consultants 
are required to provide capacity building materials, and to summarize and report important 
topics highlighted at seminars and workshops to the NEA and ADB. The consultants are also 
required to submit their reports on time.  All reports should discuss the terms of reference with 
details appropriate to the respective stage. Detailed requirements for deliverables and reports 
are included in the outline terms of reference for consultants (Appendix 3).

5
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Enhancing the Energy Regulation System 
for Low-Carbon Development and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) technical assistance (TA) will be implemented 
under the guidance of the National Energy Administration (NEA). The TA includes three outputs:  
 
(i)  an integrated study on the current energy regulation system and legislation in the 
People's Republic of China (PRC), and their adequacy for its future low-carbon 
transformation; 
(ii)  policy recommendations on drafting the energy law and amending the electricity 
law; and  
(iii)  capacity building and information dissemination. 
 
2.  The TA will be carried out by a team of experts familiar with existing institutional and 
regulation  systems  in  the  energy  sector  of the  PRC,  and  an  understanding  of  the  reform 
objectives of the National Development and Reform Commission and the NEA. The experts are 
expected to have extensive knowledge and special expertise in (i) energy development strategy, 
(ii) energy economics, (iii) energy legislation, (iv) electricity reform, (v) emergency oil stock, and 
(vi) energy-related environmental and social safeguards. The total inputs from consultants are 
estimated  to  be  34  person-months  (4  person-months  international  and  30  person-months 
national).  International  consultants  should  have  internationally  proved  track  records 
(i.e., publications or reports) in the required fields. 
 
A.  Consultants 
 
3.  Energy economists (1 international for 3 person-months and 3 national for a total of 
10 person-months). The energy economists will contribute to outputs 1–3. One of the national 
energy economists will act as the team leader responsible for preparing a policy note based on 
the main TA findings, at the completion of the TA.  
 
4.  In general, the energy economists will: 
 
(i)  review existing institutional and regulation mechanisms in the energy sector of 
the PRC, 
(ii)  review existing national and provincial laws and regulations on energy,    
(iii)  understand international best practices of energy sector reform and low-carbon 
development, and 
(iv)  help the capacity building specialist determine training requirements and develop 
capacity building materials. 
 
5.  Specifically, the energy economists will: 
 
(i)  For output 1,  
  (a)  summarize major barriers to energy sector reform in the PRC;  
(b)  analyze the potential impact of changes in the energy regulation system 
on energy development; and 
(c)  make policy recommendations for a future energy development strategy;  
 
(ii)  For output 2,  
(a)  analyze the rationale, coverage, and contents of a national energy law in 
the PRC;

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
(b)  analyze the potential impact of changes in the energy regulation system 
on energy sector development;  
(c)  examine the benefits and costs of a national emergency oil stock system 
under different operational conditions;   
(d)  evaluate the status of the power sector and the implementation problems 
of the existing electricity  law; and 
(e)  make  recommendations  for  amending  the  current  electricity  law  to 
advance power sector reform. 
 
6.  Emergency oil stock experts (2 national for 6 person-months in total). The experts will 
contribute to output 2 and are expected to: 
 
(i)  review emergency oil stock mechanisms and practices in countries within the 
Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, and summarize the 
lessons learned;   
(ii)  analyze the potential impact of an emergency oil stock system on energy sector 
development, and the roles of state-owned and commercial stocks;   
(iii)  make policy recommendations on the operational mechanism of an emergency 
oil stock; and  
(iv)  help the capacity building specialist determine training requirements and develop 
capacity building materials. 
 
7.  Legal experts (1 international for 1 person-month and 2 national for a total of 7 person-
months). The legal experts will contribute to outputs 1–3.  
 
8.  In general, the legal experts are expected to: 
 
(i)  review the existing legislation processes for energy in the PRC,   
(ii)  review and comment on policy recommendations made by other experts and 
contribute to the chapters on legal issues, and 
(iii)  help the capacity building specialist determine training requirements and develop 
capacity building materials. 
 
9.  Specifically, the legal experts are expected to: 
 
(i)  For output 1,   
(a)  analyze the current problems in energy legislation and regulation systems;  
(b)  evaluate  the  PRC’s  legislative  needs  for  its  future  low-carbon 
transformation; and 
(c)   make recommendations for future energy legislation; 
 
(ii)  For output 2,  
(a)  analyze the legal requirements and resources needed for enacting an 
energy law in the PRC;   
(b)  determine the needs of harmonizing the energy law with existing laws;  
(c)   evaluate the implementation problems of the current electricity law; and 
(d)  make recommendations for amending the current electricity law. 
 
10.  Environment and social safeguard expert (2 national for 5 person-months in total). 
The  environment  and  social  safeguard  specialists  will  contribute  to  outputs  1–3,  and  are 
expected to:

Appendix 3  11 
 
(i)  review national and provincial laws, policies, and standards for environmental 
protection;  
(ii)  estimate the possible environmental effects of recommended policies;  
(iii)  review and comment on the policy recommendations made by other experts and 
contribute the chapters on environmental and social safeguard issues; and  
(iv)  help the capacity building specialist determine training requirements and develop 
capacity building materials on safeguards. 
 
11.  Capacity building and information-sharing expert (1 national, 2 person-months). The 
training specialist will: 
(i)  work  with  other  experts  to  schedule  capacity  building  activities,  including 
seminars and workshops; 
(ii)  work  with  other  experts  to  select  international  and  national  participants  for 
seminars and workshops, as well as prepare invitation letters, as directed by the 
NEA and ADB; and 
(iii)  summarize capacity building results and report to the NEA and ADB. 
 
B.  Reporting Requirements 
 
12.  The  consultants  will  submit  (i)  an  inception  report  within  1  month  of  signing  the 
consulting contract, (ii) a midterm report within 7 months of signing the consulting contract, (iii) a 
draft final report within 12 months of signing the consulting contract, and (iv) a final report within 
1 month of receiving feedback from ADB and the NEA on the draft final report. A policy note 
summarizing the main TA findings will be submitted by month 14. All the reports should discuss 
the terms of reference with details appropriate to the respective stage.  
 
13.  All  reports  will  be  written  in  English.  National  consultants  will  be  responsible  for 
translating documents into Chinese. Three copies of each TA report will be submitted to ADB in 
English, and eight copies will be submitted to the NEA (three in English and five in Chinese). 
The consultants will present key findings in workshops and seminars.
